qas.question: What elements of language make for poetic literature?
Poetry is usually differentiated from prose by what factor?
If prose uses sentences, what is the equivalent in poetry?
Poetry was considered to need lines and meter until when?
The structure of poetry may have existed before what?
What two qualities are used in rhyming literary art?

plausible_answers.text: by its being set in verse;[a] prose is cast in sentences, poetry in lines

qas.question: How has poetry been non-traditionally distinguished from prose?
Prior to the eighteenth century, poetry was commonly understood to be what?

plausible_answers.text: "any kind of subject consisting of Rythm or Verses".

qas.question: In 1657, what was the definition used for "poetry?"
Poetry constitutes the second earliest example of literature and was sustained how?
What is a type of lyric art that uses aesthetic and rhythmic qualities?
What has non-traditionally been the distinguishing factor between poetry and prose?
How was poetry set prior to the eighteenth century?

plausible_answers.text: any kind of subject consisting of Rythm or Verses

qas.question: What is the 1558 definition of poetry?
What is poetry the latest example of?
What qualities does prosaic use to evoke meanings?
What is prose cast in if poetry is cast in sentences?

plausible_answers.text: any kind of subject consisting of Rythm or Verses

qas.question: What is the 1568 definition of poetry?
Until when was prose considered to need metrical lines?
What has poetry been confirmed to pre-date?

context: <b10_0>Poetry<b10_0/> is a form of literary art which uses <a0_0><b5_0><b15_0>aesthetic and rhythmic<b15_0/><b5_0/> qualities<a0_0/> of language to evoke meanings in addition to, or in place of, prosaic ostensible meaning. Poetry has traditionally been distinguished from prose <b6_0>by its being set in <a1_0><b11_0>verse<b11_0/><a1_0/>;[a] prose is cast in sentences, poetry in <a2_0><b16_0>lines<b16_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>; the syntax of prose is dictated by meaning, whereas that of poetry is held across metre or the visual aspects of the poem. Prior to <a3_0><b18_0>the nineteenth century<b18_0/><a3_0/>, poetry was commonly understood to be <b7_0>something set <b12_0>in metrical lines<b12_0/><b7_0/>; accordingly, in 1658 a definition of poetry is <b8_0>"<b13_0><b17_0>any kind of subject consisting of Rythm or Verses<b17_0/><b13_0/>".<b8_0/> Possibly as a result of Aristotle's influence (his Poetics), "poetry" before the nineteenth century was usually less a technical designation for verse than a normative category of fictive or rhetorical art. As a form it may pre-date <a4_0><b19_0>literacy<b19_0/><a4_0/>, with the earliest works being composed within and sustained <b9_0>by an oral tradition<b9_0/>; hence it constitutes the earliest example of <b14_0>literature<b14_0/>.
